title: John Tyrrell (actor)
text:
John Edward Tyrrell (December 7, 1900September 20, 1949) was an American film actor. He appeared in over 250 films between 1935 and 1947, known for his numerous appearances in the <a href="Three%20Stooges">Three Stooges</a>, in a total of 28 shorts with <a href="Curly%20Howard">Curly Howard</a> as a third stooge.
Career.
Tyrrell was 16 years old when he became involved in <a href="vaudeville">vaudeville</a>, part of the team Tyrrell and Mack. Like many actors in the Stooge comedies, Tyrrell was a salaried contract player. The Columbia stock company was called upon to play incidental roles in practically everything the studio produced: important films, low-budget "B" pictures, short subjects, and serials. (Some of these players graduated to stardom, like <a href="Lloyd%20Bridges">Lloyd Bridges</a>, <a href="Bruce%20Bennett">Bruce Bennett</a>, <a href="Adele%20Mara">Adele Mara</a> and <a href="Ann%20Doran">Ann Doran</a>.) John Tyrrell worked steadily at <a href="Columbia%20Pictures">Columbia Pictures</a> from 1935 to 1946 for 11 years. Occasionally, only Tyrrell's voice would be used, as a radio newsman, public-address announcer, or police-call dispatcher. Tyrrell and fellow stock player <a href="Eddie%20Laughton">Eddie Laughton</a> often appeared together in Columbia movies (frequently as mobsters waiting in a getaway car). One of Tyrrell's biggest roles was probably in the 1939 serial "<a href="Mandrake%20the%20Magician">Mandrake the Magician</a>", in which he played a masked crime lord's right-hand man. Modern viewers will also remember him in several shorts of <a href="The%20Three%20Stooges">The Three Stooges</a>, such as "<a href="A%20Plumbing%20We%20Will%20Go">A Plumbing We Will Go</a>" as Judge Hadley, B.O. Davis/Lone Wolf Louie in "<a href="So%20Long%20Mr.%20Chumps">So Long Mr. Chumps</a>", " <a href="In%20the%20Sweet%20Pie%20and%20Pie">In the Sweet Pie and Pie</a>" as the <a href="ma%C3%AEtre%20d%27">maître d'</a>, Williams, Mr. Dill in Dizzy Detectives, and other of his 28 appearances in the Three Stooges, all of them with <a href="Curly%20Howard">Curly Howard</a>.
Death.
Tyrrell's final appearance with the Three Stooges was in "<a href="Uncivil%20War%20Birds">Uncivil War Birds</a>" (1946). After spending several months at Kingsbridge Veteran's Hospital in <a href="the%20Bronx">the Bronx</a>, <a href="New%20York%20%28state%29">New York</a>, possibly due to some of his health problems, John Tyrrell died of complications from <a href="pneumonia">pneumonia</a> on September 20, 1949, at age 48.
